skill.name: pdb-database
skill.description: Access RCSB PDB for 3D protein/nucleic acid structures. Search by text/sequence/structure, download coordinates (PDB/mmCIF), retrieve metadata, for structural biology and drug discovery.
skill.summary: Access Protein Data Bank for 3D molecular structures
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate scientific skill for accessing the public RCSB Protein Data Bank. All 182 static findings are false positives. The scanner misinterpreted markdown inline code formatting (backticks) as Ruby shell execution, generic API calls to trusted public endpoints as network threats, and scientific terminology as security-sensitive patterns.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: This is legitimate debugging/testing code that makes a hardcoded curl request to the public RCSB PDB API. Arguments are safe string literals, no user input involved, no command injection risk.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/api_reference.md:32 (and 105 other locations)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The scanner misinterpreted markdown inline code formatting (backticks ` `) as Ruby backtick shell execution. All instances are markdown code delimiters in documentation, not actual shell commands. The skill contains Python code examples, not Ruby.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] network: Fetch API call at references/api_reference.md:490
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: This is documentation mentioning the Fetch API in a legitimate context. The actual code uses Python requests library to access the public RCSB PDB API endpoints.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] network: Python HTTP libraries at references/api_reference.md:113
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Legitimate use of Python requests library to access the public RCSB PDB API (https://data.rcsb.org/graphql). This is expected behavior for a data retrieval skill.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] network: Hardcoded URL at references/api_reference.md:32 (and 28 other locations)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: All hardcoded URLs are legitimate public API endpoints for RCSB PDB (data.rcsb.org, files.rcsb.org, www.rcsb.org). No external or malicious destinations.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] filesystem: Python file write/append at references/api_reference.md:407
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Legitimate file writing to save downloaded PDB structure files. This is expected functionality for a data retrieval skill, not malicious file operations.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] sensitive: Windows SAM database at references/api_reference.md:239
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The scanner matched the string 'SAM' as 'Windows SAM database'. In context, this is a sequence of amino acids in a protein sequence example (MTEYKLVVVGAGGVGKSALTIQLI...). The skill is about protein structures, not Windows security.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at references/api_reference.md:3 (and 5 other locations)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner triggered on cryptographic terminology in unrelated contexts. Line 3 mentions 'API' which contains 'DES' as substring. Line 239 contains protein sequence. This skill does not perform cryptography.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] blocker: System reconnaissance at references/api_reference.md:103 (and 6 other locations)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner matched generic terms like 'fetch', 'probe', 'scan' in documentation. These are legitimate API operations, not system reconnaissance. The skill only accesses public scientific databases.

This heuristic finding is incorrect. The skill legitimately accesses public scientific databases. Network access is to trusted RCSB PDB endpoints. There are no credentials involved, no obfuscation, and no malicious intent.

False positive triggered by combination of legitimate features: file operations (saving PDB files), network access (to public API), and Python HTTP libraries. This is standard functionality for a data retrieval skill.

content.user_title: Search Protein Data Bank for molecular structures
content.value_statement: Access the RCSB Protein Data Bank to search for and download 3D structures of proteins and nucleic acids. This skill enables structural biology research, drug discovery, and protein engineering by providing programmatic access to over 200,000 experimentally determined and computationally modeled molecular structures.
actual_capabilities: Search PDB by text, protein name, or keywords
Search by sequence similarity using MMseqs2
Search by 3D structure similarity using BioZernike
Download coordinate files in PDB, mmCIF, or BinaryCIF formats
Retrieve metadata including experimental method, resolution, and deposition date
Perform batch operations across multiple structures
limitations: Requires internet connection to access RCSB PDB public API
Rate limits apply for high-volume requests
Downloaded files require external tools like BioPython for analysis

use_cases.title: Find drug-target complexes
use_cases.description: Search for protein-ligand complexes to understand binding sites and design new therapeutics.

use_cases.title: Compare mutant structures
use_cases.description: Find homologous structures and analyze sequence-structure relationships for protein design.

use_cases.title: Download structures for analysis
use_cases.description: Retrieve 3D coordinates for computational analysis, visualization, and structure-based research.

prompt_templates.title: Basic structure search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find the PDB entry for hemoglobin and tell me its resolution and experimental method.

prompt_templates.title: Sequence search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find proteins with sequences similar to: MTEYKLVVVGAGGVGKSALTIQLIQNHFVDEYDPTIEDSYRKQVVID

prompt_templates.title: Filter by quality
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all human protein structures with resolution better than 2.0 Angstroms determined by X-ray crystallography.

prompt_templates.title: Batch download
prompt_templates.prompt: Download the PDB files for entries 4HHB, 1MBN, and 1GZX in mmCIF format.

output_examples.input: Find structures similar to human hemoglobin
output: â€¢ 4HHB - Hemoglobin (1.74 Ã…, X-RAY DIFFRACTION, Homo sapiens)
â€¢ 1HHO - Hemoglobin (2.10 Ã…, X-RAY DIFFRACTION, Pan troglodytes)
â€¢ 1A3N - Hemoglobin (2.50 Ã…, X-RAY DIFFRACTION, Equus caballus)

best_practices: Use the Search API to get PDB IDs first, then fetch detailed data to minimize API calls.
Implement rate limiting with delays between requests to avoid hitting API limits.
Cache frequently accessed data locally to reduce redundant network requests.
anti_patterns: Making individual API calls in a loop without delays - this will trigger rate limits.
Downloading entire database when only specific entries are needed.
Not checking API response status codes before processing data.

faq.question: What is the difference between PDB and mmCIF formats?
faq.answer: PDB is the legacy text format with column constraints. mmCIF is the modern standard that handles larger structures and more metadata.

faq.question: How do I parse downloaded structure files?
faq.answer: Use BioPython's PDBParser for PDB files or the mmCIF parser for mmCIF format. Both can iterate through atoms and residues.

faq.question: What is a good resolution for crystal structures?
faq.answer: High-resolution structures are below 2.0 Ã…. Structures between 2.0-3.0 Ã… are moderate quality. Above 3.0 Ã… is lower resolution.

faq.question: How do I search by protein sequence?
faq.answer: Use SequenceQuery with your amino acid sequence. Set evalue_cutoff and identity_cutoff to filter results by similarity.

faq.question: What are biological assemblies?
faq.answer: Biological assemblies represent the functional form of a macromolecule, which may differ from the crystallographic asymmetric unit.

faq.question: Can I search for ligand-bound structures?
faq.answer: Yes, use AttributeQuery with rcsb_nonpolymer_entity_instance_container_identifiers.comp_id to find structures containing specific ligands like ATP or heme.
